article.title: Exabyte
article.paragraph: Aboutthe unit of informationthe company that manufactured data backup productsExabyte (company)Quantities of bytesTheexabyteis a multiple of the unitbyteforComputer data storagedigital information. TheSI prefixprefixexa-exaindicates multiplication by the sixth power of 1000 (1018) in theInternational System of Units(SI). Therefore, one exabyte is onequintillionbytes(Long and short scalesshort scale). The symbol for the exabyte isEB.
A related unit, theexbibyte, using abinary prefix, is equal togaps10246bytes, about 15% larger.

list.listitem: A processor with a64-bit computing64-bitaddress bus canaddress spaceaddress16exbibytesof memory,Cite webhttp://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/zos/basics/index.jsp?topicA brief history of virtual storage and 64-bit addressability2007-02-17which is over 18 exabytes.

The world's technological capacity to store information grew from 2.6 ("optimally compressed") exabytes in 1986 to 15.8 in 1993, over 54.5 in 2000, and to 295 (optimally compressed) exabytes in 2007. This is equivalent to less than oneCompact discCD(650 MB) per person in 1986 (539 MB per person), roughly four in 1993, 12 in 2000, and almost 61 in 2007. Piling up the imagined 404 billion CDs from 2007 would create a stack from theearthto themoonand a quarter of this distance beyond (with 1.2 mm thickness per CD).Martin Hilbert and Priscila Lpez, "The Worlds Technological Capacity to Store, Communicate, and Compute Information",Science (journal)Science, 332(6025), 2011: 6065; see also"free access to the study"and"video animation".

The world's technological capacity to receive information through one-waybroadcastnetworks was 432 exabytes of information in 1986, 715 exabytes in 1993, 1,200 exabytes in 2000, and 1,900 in 2007 (and with all the preceding examples assuming that those figures represent "optimally compressed" data).

The world's effective capacity to exchange information through two-waytelecommunicationnetworks was 0.281 exabytes of information in 1986, 0.471 in 1993, 2.2 in 2000, and 65 exabytes in 2007 (yet again, all such amounts listed are strictly working off the basis that the data was in an "optimally compressed" form).

In 2004, the global monthlyInternet trafficpassed 1 exabyte for the first time. article.heading: All words ever spoken
article.paragraph: A popular expression claims that "all words ever spoken by human beings" could be stored in approximately 5 exabytes of dataCite webhttp://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/12/opinion/12WED4.html[[New York Times]]Trying to Measure the Amount of Information That Humans CreateVerlyn Klinkenborg2003-11-122006-07-19(login)Cite webhttp://searchstorage.techtarget.com/sDefinition/0,,sid5_gci944596,00.htmlHow many bytes for...techtarget.com2006-07-19Cite webhttp://news.uns.purdue.edu/html3month/2005/051206.McKay.petabyte.html'Robbie the Robot' making data easier to mine2005-12-06purdue.edu2007-02-17(although this project is now outdated and therefore not entirely accurate), often citing a project at theUC Berkeley School of Informationin support.Cite webhttp://www2.sims.berkeley.edu/research/projects/how-much-info-2003/How Much Information? 2003berkeley.edu2006-07-19The 2003 University of California Berkeley report credits the estimate to the website ofCaltechresearcher Roy Williams, where the statement can be found as early as May 1999.Cite webhttp://web.archive.org/web/19990508062723/http://www.ccsf.caltech.edu/~roy/dataquan/Data Powers of TenRoy Williams1999-05-082006-07-19http://www.ccsf.caltech.edu/~roy/dataquan/This statement has been criticized.Cite webMark LibermanMark Libermanhttp://itre.cis.upenn.edu/~myl/languagelog/archives/000110.htmlMore on the 5 exabyte mistake2003-11-12upenn.edu2006-07-19Cite webhttp://brian.carnell.com/archives/years/2003/12/000022.htmlHow Much Storage Is Required to Store Every Word Ever Spoken by Human Beings?2003-12-31Brian Carnellbrian.carnell.com2006-07-19http://web.archive.org/web/20060206081135/http://brian.carnell.com/archives/years/2003/12/000022.html2006-02-06Mark Libermancalculated the storage requirements for all human speech at 42zettabytes(42,000 exabytes, and 8,400 times the original estimate), if digitized as 16 kHz 16-bit audio, although he did freely confess that "maybe the authors [of the exabyte estimate] were thinking about text".Cite webhttp://itre.cis.upenn.edu/~myl/languagelog/archives/000087.htmlZettascale LinguisticsMark LibermanMark Liberman2003-11-03upenn.edu2007-02-17

Earlier studies from theUniversity of California, Berkeley, estimated that by the end of 1999, the sum of human-produced information (including all audio, video recordings, and text/books) was about 12 exabytes of data.Cite webhttp://www.cio.com/archive/092203/enriquez.htmlThe Data That Defines UsFall–Winter 2003Juan EnriquezCIO Magazine2006-07-19The 2003 Berkeley report stated that in 2002 alone, "telephone calls worldwide on bothlandlinesand mobile phones contained 17.3 exabytes of new information if stored in digital form" and that "it would take 9.25 exabytes of storage to hold all U.S. [telephone] calls each year".International Data Corporationestimates that approximately 160 exabytes of digital information were created, captured, and replicated worldwide in 2006.Cite webhttp://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D8NMAG802.htm[[BusinessWeek]]So much data, relatively little space[[Brian Bergstein]]2007-03-052007-03-05Research fromUniversity of Southern Californiaestimates that the amount of data stored in the world by 2007 was 295 exabytes and the amount of information shared on two-way communications technology, such as cell phones in 2007 as 65 exabytes.Cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-12419672[[BBC]]Global data storage calculated at 295 exabytesJon Stewart2011-02-11Cite webhttp://uscnews.usc.edu/science_technology/how_much_information_is_there_in_the_world.html[[University of Southern California|USC]]How Much Information Is There in the World?Suzanne Wu2011-02-10
article.heading: Library of Congress
article.paragraph: The content of theLibrary of Congressis commonly estimated to hold 10 terabytes of data in all printed material. Recent estimates of the size including audio, video, and digital materials start at 3 petabytescite webhttp://blogs.loc.gov/digitalpreservation/2012/04/a-library-of-congress-worth-of-data-its-all-in-how-you-define-it/ A "Library of Congress" Worth of Data: It’s All In How You Define It 2012-04-25 Leslie Johnston to 20 petabytes. Therefore, one exabyte could hold a hundred thousand times the printed material, or 500 to 3000 times all content of the Library of Congress.
article.heading: Google
